all_paragraphs: Before you analyze data, one of the first things you have to perform is data visualization. In Python, there are a number of high-quality visualization libraries. The most popular general-purpose visualization library is Matplotlib¹, which mainly focuses on generating static publication-quality 2D and 3D graphs. We can use it for many different plots such as histograms, bar plots, heat maps, line plots, scatter plots, and many others.
There are some of the important concepts that you shall come across and use in Matplotlib, and their meanings or roles.
A Figure can contain multiple Axes instances, for example, to show multiple panels in a figure or to show insets within another Axes instance.
The Matplotlib library might seem rather complex at first, but with basic coding knowledge, it should be easier for you. The following is a list of the plots you will use in Matplotlib.
In addition, if you frequently work with images, you should use the following image functions.
All the scripts in this book have been executed via the Jupyter notebook. Therefore, you should have the Jupyter notebook installed or create an account on Saturn Cloud.
Let’s see how to use it. We must first import the pyplot module from our Matplotlib package before we can create a plot.

We will use the plt.style directive to choose appropriate aesthetic styles for our figures. Here we will set the default style, which ensures that the plots we create use the default Matplotlib style.

You also can use different styles. Read further here³. Note that the stylesheets used here are supported as of Matplotlib version 1.5, so if you are using an earlier version of Matplotlib, only the default style is available.

To adjust the color, you can use the color keyword, which accepts a string argument representing virtually any imaginable color. The color can be specified in a variety of ways.
If no color is specified, Matplotlib will automatically cycle through a set of default colors for multiple lines.

The most basic method to adjust axis limits is to use the plt.xlim() and plt.ylim() methods.
If you want either axis to be displayed in reverse, simply execute this command.
In addition, we also can set the x and y limits with a single call by passing a list that specifies [x-min, x-max, y-min, y-max].
We can create the labeling of plots such as titles, axis labels, and simple legends.

Creating a legend can be done via the plt.legend() method.

A logarithmic plot is essentially a basic plot, but it is set on a logarithmic scale. The difference between this and a normal linear scale is that the intervals are set in order of their magnitude. We have two different types of log plots.

A scatter plot is used to plot the relationship between two numeric columns in the form of scattered points. Normally, a scatter plot is used when for each value in the x-axis, there are multiple values in the y-axis.

Using the plt.scatter() function to create scatter plots as follows. For example, we use the Iris data from the sklearn library, where each sample is one of three types of flowers that have had the size of its petals and sepals carefully measured.

We can explore simultaneously four different dimensions of the data: the (x, y) location of each point corresponds to the sepal length and width, the size of the point is related to the petal width, and the color is related to the particular species of flower.
